Business.1.1.title: Have you identified the main business drivers?
Business.1.1.remarks: Example business drivers: cyber crime prevention, risk reduction, law / regulation, audit / compliance, business continuity
guidances: Some business drivers have been identified
Most business drivers have been identified
All business drivers are well known within the SOC

Business.1.2.title: Have you documented the main business drivers?
Business.1.2.remarks: Documentation of business drivers is important for demonstrable business alignment
guidances: Single document, full description of business drivers
Document completed, approved and formally published

Business.1.3.title: Do you use business drivers in the decision making process?
Business.1.3.remarks: e.g. to determine priorities or make decisions regarding the on-boarding of new services or operations
guidances: Business drivers are not part of decision making
Business drivers are referred to on an ad-hoc basis
Business drivers are occasionally used in decisions
Business drivers are used in most decisions
Business drivers are used in all relevant decisions

Business.1.4.title: Do you regularly check if the current service catalogue is aligned with business drivers?
Business.1.4.remarks: i.e. do you check for services or operations that outside the scope of business drivers?
guidances: Service catalogue has not been checked for alignment
Alignment is performed on an ad-hoc basis
Alignment was performed but not maintained
Alignment is performed and maintained regularly
Every change in the catalogue is checked against drivers

Business.1.5.title: Have the business drivers been validated with business stakeholders?
Business.1.5.remarks: Business stakeholders can be C-level management
guidances: Business drivers have not been validated
Basic awareness of SOC drivers exists among stakeholders
Stakeholders informally informed of business drivers
Alignment of SOC drivers with stakeholders is performed
Business drivers are formally validated by stakeholders

Business.2.1.title: Have you identified the SOC customers?
Business.2.1.remarks: Types of customers, customer requirements / expectations, etc.
guidances: All customers are identified, including relevance and context

Business.2.2.title: Please specify your customers:
Business.2.2.remarks: Use this a guideline for answering 2.1 This is also potentially useful for insights and comparison with previous assessments

Business.2.2.1.title: Legal
Business.2.2.1.remarks: Legal department, may be a stakeholder for privacy, or may request forensic investigation to the SOC

Business.2.2.2.title: Audit
Business.2.2.2.remarks: The audit department can be supported by logging provided by the SOC

Business.2.2.3.title: Engineering / R&D
Business.2.2.3.remarks: The engineering departments deal with Intellectual Property that may require additional access monitoring

Business.2.2.4.title: IT
Business.2.2.4.remarks: IT departments can be supported by monitoring for anomalies in their infrastructure and systems

Business.2.2.5.title: Business
Business.2.2.5.remarks: Business should be the most important customer, as all SOC activities ultimately support business processes

Business.2.2.6.title: External customers
Business.2.2.6.remarks: External customers mostly apply to managed service providers

Business.2.2.7.title: (Senior) Management
Business.2.2.7.remarks: Senior management may be a direct SOC customer, depending on organization hierarchy

Business.2.3.title: Have you documented the main SOC customers?
Business.2.3.remarks: Formal registration of customer contact details, place in the organization, geolocation, etc.
guidances: Single document, full description of SOC customers
Document completed, approved and formally published

Business.2.4.title: Do you differentiate output towards these specific customers?
Business.2.4.remarks: For example, are communication style and contents to Business customers different than that to IT?
guidances: Output is the same for all customers
All important customers receive differentiated output
All customers receive specific output based on context and type

Business.2.5.title: Do you have service level agreements with these customers?
Business.2.5.remarks: Service level agreements are used to provide standardized services operating within known boundaries
guidances: No contract in place, ad-hoc agreements made
Basic contract in place, not formally signed of
Contract signed, but not regularly reviewed
Contract signed, approved by- and regularly reviewed with customers

Business.2.6.title: Do you regularly send updates to your customers?
Business.2.6.remarks: For example: changes in service scope or delivery. Can also be reports, dashboards, etc.
guidances: Ad-hoc updates sent to some customers
Frequent updates sent to most customers
Periodical updates sent to all customers
Periodical updates sent and discussed with all customers

Business.2.7.title: Do you actively measure and manage customer satisfaction?
Business.2.7.remarks: Understanding customer satisfaction will help to better align with business needs
guidances: Customer satisfaction not measured or managed
Customer satisfaction managed in ad-hoc fashion
Customer satisfaction metrics defined, not applied structurally
Customer satisfaction measured structurally, not actively managed
Customer satisfaction fully managed and improved over time

Business.3.1.title: Does the SOC have a formal charter document in place?
guidances: Single charter, full description of SOC strategic elements
Charter completed, approved and formally published

Business.3.2.title: Please specify elements of the charter document:

Business.3.2.1.title: Mission
Business.3.2.1.remarks: A SOC mission should be established to provide insight into the reason for existence of the SOC

Business.3.2.2.title: Vision
Business.3.2.2.remarks: A vision should be created to determine long-term goals for the SOC

Business.3.2.3.title: Strategy
Business.3.2.3.remarks: A strategy should be in place to show how to meet goals and targets set by mission and vision

Business.3.2.4.title: Service Scope
Business.3.2.4.remarks: Service scope is documented to provide insight into SOC service delivery

Business.3.2.5.title: Deliverables
Business.3.2.5.remarks: The output provided by the SOC, for example: reports, incidents, investigations, advisories, etc.

Business.3.2.7.title: Accountability
Business.3.2.7.remarks: Accountability for the SOC for actions taken

Business.3.2.9.title: Stakeholders
Business.3.2.9.remarks: All relevant stakeholders for the SOC

Business.3.2.10.title: Objectives / Goals
Business.3.2.10.remarks: Objectives and goals should be concrete and measurable so that they are fit for reporting purposes

Business.3.2.11.title: Statement of success
Business.3.2.11.remarks: A statement of success is used to determine when the SOC is successful. Should be aligned with goals and objectives

Business.3.3.title: Is the SOC charter document regularly updated?
Business.3.3.remarks: Regularity should be matched to your own internal policy. At least yearly is recommended
guidances: Charter is updated on ad-hoc basis
Charter is updated on major changes in business strategy
Charter periodically updated and realigned with business strategy

Business.3.4.title: Is the SOC charter document approved by the business / CISO?
Business.3.4.remarks: Approval from the relevant stakeholders will aid in business support for SOC operations
guidances: Business / CISO has basic awareness of the charter
Business / CISO has full awareness of the charter
Business / CISO approves of the content, but not formally
Charter is formally approved by the business / CISO

Business.3.5.title: Are all stakeholders familiar with the SOC charter document contents?
Business.3.5.remarks: Making stakeholders aware of the contents helps in getting organizational support for security operations
guidances: Stakeholders are unfamiliar with the charter
Some stakeholders are aware of the charter, but not its contents
Some stakeholders are aware of the charter and its contents
All stakeholders are aware, not all stakeholders know its contents
All Stakeholders are aware of the charter and its contents

Business.4.1.title: Does the SOC have a governance process in place?
Business.4.1.remarks: A governance process is required to determine the way the SOC should be managed
guidances: SOC governance process is not in place
SOC governance is done in an ad-hoc fashion
Several governance elements are in place, but not structurally
Formal governance process is in place that covers most SOC aspects
Formal governance process is in place and covers all SOC aspects

Business.4.2.title: Have all governance elements been identified?
Business.4.2.remarks: Possible governance elements can be found in under 4.3
guidances: No governance elements have been identified
Some governance elements are identified and governed ad-hoc
Some governance elements are identified and governed actively
Most governance elements are identified and actively governed
All elements are identified and actively governed

Business.4.3.1.title: Business Alignment
Business.4.3.1.remarks: Aligning SOC operations to business needs

Business.4.3.2.title: Accountability
Business.4.3.2.remarks: Note that this can be part of the SOC charter document. This does not automatically make it part of the governance process

Business.4.3.3.title: Sponsorship
Business.4.3.3.remarks: Can be part of stakeholder management

Business.4.3.4.title: Mandate
Business.4.3.4.remarks: Mandate for the SOC should be established so that the SOC can take action in crisis situations

Business.4.3.5.title: Relationships & Third Party Management
Business.4.3.5.remarks: Both management of internal and external relationships

Business.4.3.6.title: Vendor Engagement
Business.4.3.6.remarks: For example: active involvement of vendors in the creation of a vision and strategy for the SOC

Business.4.3.7.title: Service Commitment
Business.4.3.7.remarks: For example: service level agreements and IT controls

Business.4.3.8.title: Project / Program Management
Business.4.3.8.remarks: Project management for individual projects within the SOC / program management for larger transitions

Business.4.3.9.title: Continual Improvement
Business.4.3.9.remarks: Improvement of the SOC and of SOC management

Business.4.3.10.title: Span of control / federation governance
Business.4.3.10.remarks: Especially important for SOC setups where multiple SOCs exist within the same company

Business.4.3.11.title: Outsourced service management
Business.4.3.11.remarks: Especially important for hybrid SOC setups. When using outsourcing, SLAs and oversight should be in place

Business.4.3.12.title: SOC KPIs & Metrics
Business.4.3.12.remarks: These are discussed in more detail in the Process section regarding reporting

Business.4.3.13.title: SOC risk management
Business.4.3.13.remarks: Identification of- and dealing with risk (business, people, process and technology risk) within the SOC

Business.4.3.14.title: Customer Engagement / Satisfaction
Business.4.3.14.remarks: Are customers an integral part of your security operations? Is their satisfaction of SOC services every inquired about?

Business.4.4.title: Is cost management in place?
Business.4.4.remarks: Managing costs is required to justify budget allocation for the SOC and ensure continued service delivery in the future
guidances: Costs visible, basic budget allocation in place
Costs fully visible and mostly managed, forecasting in place
Costs fully managed, not formally aligned with business stakeholders
Costs fully managed and formally aligned with business stakeholders

Business.4.5.1.title: People cost
Business.4.5.1.remarks: Costs associated with employees. Should be managed to prove FTE requirements to stakeholders

Business.4.5.2.title: Process cost
Business.4.5.2.remarks: Cost associated with processes. Should be managed to ensure process elements can be delivered

Business.4.5.3.title: Technology cost
Business.4.5.3.remarks: Cost associated with technology. Should be managed to prove budget requirements for new technology or replacement

Business.4.5.4.title: Services cost
Business.4.5.4.remarks: Cost associated with service delivery. Especially important for managed service providers to ensure a healthy business model

Business.4.5.5.title: Facility cost
Business.4.5.5.remarks: Cost associated with facilities used by the SOC

Business.4.5.6.title: Budget forecasting
Business.4.5.6.remarks: Forecasting of required budget over time. Should be aligned with business needs; increased spending must be justified

Business.4.5.7.title: Budget alignment
Business.4.5.7.remarks: Alignment of budget with business requirements and drivers to ensure balanced spending on the SOC

Business.4.5.8.title: Return on investment
Business.4.5.8.remarks: Prove the return on investment to stakeholders to ensure continued budget allocation

Business.4.6.title: Are all governance elements formally documented?
Business.4.6.remarks: Formal documentation should be signed off and stored in a quality management system
guidances: Single document, full description of governance elements
Governance document completed, approved and formally published

Business.4.7.title: Are SOC governance meetings regularly held?
Business.4.7.remarks: Meetings at different levels (operational, tactical, strategic) should be formalised in Terms of Reference (ToR) and driven by metrics
guidances: Governance meetings held in an ad-hoc fashion
Governance meetings at different levels scheduled and structured
Governance meetings at different levels scheduled, ToR formalised

Business.4.8.title: Is the governance process regularly reviewed?
Business.4.8.remarks: Frequency should be matched to your own internal policy. At least yearly is recommended
guidances: Governance process is reviewed in an ad-hoc fashion
Process is reviewed using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
Process is regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Process is regularly and formally reviewed and updated with findings

Business.4.9.title: Is the governance process aligned with all stakeholders?
Business.4.9.remarks: Alignment will help the SOC obtain required mandate, budget and management support
guidances: Stakeholders are unfamiliar with the process
Some stakeholders are aware of the process, but not its details
Some stakeholders are aware of the process and its details
All stakeholders are aware, not all stakeholders know its details
All stakeholders are aware of the process and its details

Business.4.10.title: Is the SOC regularly audited or subjected to (external) assessments?
Business.4.10.remarks: Frequency should be matched to the SOC policy. At least yearly is recommended. 3rd party assessments have a higher objectivity
guidances: The SOC is assessed in an ad-hoc fashion
The SOC is assessed using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
The SOC is regularly and informally assessed
The SOC is regularly and formally assessed by a third party

Business.4.11.title: Is there an active cooperation with other SOCs (external)?
Business.4.11.remarks: Exchange of best practices, intelligence and actions on threats with other SOCs is vital for improving cyber defence
guidances: Some information exchange with external SOCs
Information exchanged regularly, cooperation not formalized
Continuous formalized active cooperation and information exchange

Business.5.1.title: Is there an information security policy in place that supports the SOC activities?
Business.5.1.remarks: A clear security policy that supports SOC operations provides guidance and helps to enforce mandate for the SOC in the organisation
guidances: No formal information security policy in place
Information security in place, no mention of SOC activities
Policy in place, SOC activities mentioned without mandate
Policy in place, SOC activities mentioned in detail with mandate
Policy with SOC activities and mandate in place, actively communicated

Business.5.2.title: Has a SOC policy been created?
Business.5.2.remarks: A SOC policy is to outline the rules to which SOC personnel and SOC management needs to adhere
guidances: Single document, full description of SOC policy elements
SOC policy document completed, approved and formally published

Business.5.3.title: Please specify elements of the SOC policy

Business.5.3.1.title: Code of conduct
Business.5.3.1.remarks: How to behave in the SOC, mandatory and optional meetings, SOC culture, repercussions for non-compliance, etc.

Business.5.3.2.title: Rules of engagement & responsibilities
Business.5.3.2.remarks: What activities can and can not be performed as part of the job

Business.5.3.3.title: Review frequency of documentation
Business.5.3.3.remarks: What documentation is subjected to review and how often that documentation needs to be reviewed

Business.5.3.4.title: SOC assessment frequency and type
Business.5.3.4.remarks: How often the SOC is assessed and in what manner (self-assessment, audit, external assessment, etc.)

Business.5.3.5.title: Knowledge exchange and maintenance
Business.5.3.5.remarks: The means (meetings and platforms) for knowledge exchange and rules for maintenance of knowledge bases

Business.5.3.6.title: Exercise frequency
Business.5.3.6.remarks: Frequency and type (table top, cyber range, red team, etc.) of exercises in the SOC

Business.5.3.7.title: Usage of TLP
Business.5.3.7.remarks: Information exchange protocols. Especially important for collaborations outside the organisation

Business.5.3.8.title: Working agreements
Business.5.3.8.remarks: Agreements on length of meetings, length of agile sprints, transparency of completed work, etc.

Business.5.4.title: Is the SOC consulted in the creation and updates of operational security policy?
Business.5.4.remarks: Consulting the SOC in the creation of security policy will ensure that SOC activities are properly mentioned and enforceable
guidances: SOC not consulted or informed of policy creation or policy updates
SOC informed of policy creation and updates only
SOC consulted before policy creation and updates, not actively involved
SOC consulted before policy creation and updates, performs reviews
Full involvement of the SOC in the creation of operational security policy

Business.5.5.title: Is a reporting policy for security incidents in place?
Business.5.5.remarks: A reporting policy for security incidents will aid the SOC in identifying incidents and threats in the organization
guidances: Policy in place, no mention of the SOC
Policy in place, role of the SOC in security incidents mentioned
Policy in place with all SOC activities, no central point for reporting
Policy & central point for reporting in place, SOC part of the workflow

Business.5.6.title: Is a privacy policy regarding security monitoring of employees in place?
Business.5.6.remarks: A privacy policy should state that monitoring of employees is possible within acceptable limits
guidances: Information regarding privacy is scattered across documents
A policy exists, but has not been accepted formally
A formal policy exists, its contents are known to all employees
A formal policy exists, its contents are accepted by all employees

Business.5.7.title: Does the SOC operate in compliance with all applicable privacy laws and regulations?
Business.5.7.remarks: Local laws and regulations as well as company policy may apply and should all be considered
guidances: Regulations are not known and the SOC is non-compliant
Some regulations are known and the SOC is non-compliant
Most regulations are known and the SOC is partially compliant
Regulations are fully known and the SOC is mostly compliant
Regulations are fully known and the SOC is fully compliant

Business.5.8.title: Does the SOC cooperate with legal departments regarding privacy matters?
Business.5.8.remarks: Cooperation will ensure that the SOC is enabled to perform activities, rather than blocked
guidances: There is no cooperation between the SOC and legal
There is some ad-hoc cooperation between SOC and legal
There is structural cooperation between SOC and legal
Alignment exists between SOC and legal
Full and regular alignment exists between SOC and legal

Business.5.9.title: Are specific procedures in place for dealing with privacy related investigations?
Business.5.9.remarks: Privacy related issues require careful examination, especially those potentially leading to court cases
guidances: Single document, full description of privacy investigations
Procedure completed, approved and formally published

Business.5.10.title: Is the SOC aware of all information that it processes and is subject to privacy regulations?
Business.5.10.remarks: Such information includes IP addresses, customer identifiers, user names, host names (for personally owned devices), etc.
guidances: The SOC is unaware of any information
The SOC is aware of such information, no formal identification
The SOC is fully aware, some information is formally identified
Most privacy related information is identified and documented
All privacy related information is identified and documented

Business.5.11.title: Is a Privacy Impact Assessment (PIA) regularly conducted?
Business.5.11.remarks: Can be used to determine the impact of monitoring on privacy, and can help uncover potential violations
guidances: PIAs are conducted in an ad-hoc fashion
PIAs are conducted using a structured approach in an ad-hoc fashion
PIAs are conducted informally and regularly
PIAs are conducted formally and regularly

People.1.1.title: How many FTEâ€™s are in your SOC?
People.1.1.remarks: Include both internal and external FTE's

People.1.2.title: Do you use external employees / contractors in your SOC?
People.1.2.remarks: External employees can be hired experts to fill in vacant positions or perform project activities

People.1.2.1.title: If yes, specify the number of external FTE's

People.1.3.title: Does the current size of the SOC meet FTE requirements?
People.1.3.remarks: i.e. is the SOC size sufficient to realize business goals?
guidances: The SOC is either heavily overstaffed or understaffed
The SOC is overstaffed or understaffed
The SOC is somewhat overstaffed or understaffed
The SOC mostly meets FTE requirements
The SOC is staffed to full satisfaction in terms of FTE requirements

People.1.4.title: Does the SOC meet requirements for internal to external employee FTE ratio?
People.1.4.remarks: Note: requirements do not need to be explicit. Set importance to 'None' if you have no external employees.
guidances: There are either way too few or too many external employees
There are too few or too many external employees
The SOC has somewhat too many or too few external employees
The SOC mostly meets requirements for external employee FTE count
The external employee ratio meets all requirements

People.1.5.title: Does the SOC meet requirements for internal to external employee skillset?
People.1.5.remarks: i.e. Are there any crucial skills amongst external employees? Set importance to 'None' if you have no external employees
guidances: There are too many skills only present within the external employees
Some required skills are not present internally, and not transferred
Some required skills are not present internally, but being transferred
Most skills are covered with internal employees
All required skills are covered with internal employees as well

People.1.6.title: Are all positions filled?
People.1.6.remarks: Unfilled positions may be due to deficiencies in the recruitment process
guidances: Not all positions filled, service delivery cannot be assured
Sufficient positions filled to ensure service delivery
All positions currently filled, not meeting external ration requirements
All positions currently filled, meeting external ratio requirements

People.1.7.title: Do you have a recruitment process in place?
People.1.7.remarks: A recruitment process is required to obtain new employees in a market where talent is scarce [1]
guidances: There is no recruitment process in place
Recruitment is performed at an ad-hoc basis
A basic recruitment process is in place
A full recruitment process is in place, but not performing effectively
A full recruitment process is in place and performing effectively

People.1.8.title: Do you have a talent acquisition process in place?
People.1.8.remarks: Talent recruitment can be vital for SOC success, but talent retaining is equally important
guidances: No talent acquisition process in place
Talent acquisition is performed at an ad-hoc basis
A basic talent acquisition process is in place
A full acquisition process is in place, but not performing effectively
A full acquisition process is in place and performing effectively

People.1.9.title: Do you have specific KSAOs established for SOC personnel?
People.1.9.remarks: Knowledge, Skills, Abilities and Other attributes (KSAOs) should be in place: technical, cognitive, social and character [2], [3]
guidances: KSOAs are used ad-hoc in staffing attempts
A basic standardized KSAO set is created
A full KSAO is created, but not actively used in staffing
A full KSAO is created, regularly updated and actively used in staffing

People.1.10.title: Do you actively seek to create a psychologically safe environment for SOC personnel?
People.1.10.remarks: A psychologically safe environment is an environment where everyone is able to speak their mind and feel valued
guidances: A safe environment is not actively created
Basic awareness of a safe environment exists, but is not implemented
A safe environment has been established, but not actively managed
A safe environment has been established, and actively managed
A safe and actively managed environment exists and is evaluated

People.2.1.title: Do you formally differentiate roles within the SOC?
People.2.1.remarks: Use the roles in 2.2 to determine if you have all roles required in the SOC
guidances: No roles are used in the SOC
Some roles exist, but are not actively being used
Some roles exist, and are actively being used
All roles are fully in use, but not formalized
All roles are fully in use and formalized

People.2.2.title: Which of the following roles are present in your SOC?

People.2.2.1.title: Security Analyst
People.2.2.1.remarks: Primarily responsible for triage and analysis of security alerts

People.2.2.2.title: Security / Systems Engineer
People.2.2.2.remarks: Primarily responsible for technical / functional maintenance of security systems

People.2.2.3.title: Forensic Analyst
People.2.2.3.remarks: Primarily responsible for in-depth analysis and security projects

People.2.2.4.title: Security Architect
People.2.2.4.remarks: Primarily responsible for technical architecture for security systems used within the SOC

People.2.2.5.title: Threat Intelligence Analyst
People.2.2.5.remarks: Primarily responsible for analysis of threat intelligence

People.2.2.6.title: Data Scientist
People.2.2.6.remarks: Primarily responsible for big data security analytics

People.2.2.7.title: SOC Manager
People.2.2.7.remarks: Primarily responsible for managing SOC services

People.2.2.8.title: Team Leader
People.2.2.8.remarks: Primarily responsible for leading a team of other, for example, analysts and engineers

People.2.2.9.title: Incident Handler
People.2.2.9.remarks: Primarily responsible for executing security incident management workflows

People.2.2.10.title: Incident Manager
People.2.2.10.remarks: Primarily responsible for ensuring correct and timely management and escalation of security incidents

People.2.2.11.title: Penetration Tester
People.2.2.11.remarks: Primarily responsible for testing applications and systems for security weaknesses

People.2.2.12.title: Detection engineer
People.2.2.12.remarks: Primarily responsible for creating and updating detection analytics

People.2.2.13.title: Automation engineer
People.2.2.13.remarks: Primarily responsible for automation of repetitive SOC tasks

People.2.3.title: Do you differentiate tiers within these roles?
People.2.3.remarks: If you have no tiers, and you feel this is not a restriction, select importance 'None'
guidances: No tiers exist within these roles
Some tiers exist, but are not actively being used
Some tiers exist, and are actively being used
All tiers are fully in use, but not formalized
All relevant roles are tiered and formalized

People.2.4.title: Are all roles sufficiently staffed?
People.2.4.remarks: Consider the staffing levels (desired FTE count) as well as knowledge and experience for all roles
guidances: None of the roles meets FTE requirements
All vital roles and most other roles meet FTE requirements
All roles fully meet FTE requirements

People.2.5.title: Is there a role-based hierarchy in your SOC?
People.2.5.remarks: If you have no hierarchy, and you feel this is not a restriction, select importance 'None'
guidances: A basic hierarchy exists, but is not fully operational
A basic hierarchy is in place and fully operational
A full hierarchy is in place, but not formalized
A full hierarchy is in place and formalized

People.2.6.title: Have you formally documented all SOC roles?
People.2.6.remarks: Possible documentation elements can be found in under 2.7
guidances: Single document, full description of SOC roles
Document completed, approved and formally published

People.2.7.title: Please specify elements in  the role documentation:

People.2.7.1.title: Role description
People.2.7.1.remarks: A formal description of the role

People.2.7.2.title: Role tasks
People.2.7.2.remarks: A description of tasks that are part of the role

People.2.7.4.title: Role expectations
People.2.7.4.remarks: This is an extension of responsibilities. Example expectation: take a pro-active leading role in case of security incidents

People.2.7.5.title: Required technical skills
People.2.7.5.remarks: e.g. experience with specific technologies or products

People.2.7.8.title: Required or preferred certifications
People.2.7.8.remarks: e.g. technical security certifications or security management certifications

People.2.8.title: Are responsibilities for each role understood?
People.2.8.remarks: Responsibilities for each role should be clearly understood by all SOC personnel
guidances: Responsibilities for some roles understood and adhered to
Responsibilities for all roles mostly understood and adhered to
Full understanding of responsibilities formalized in training sessions

People.2.9.title: Have you documented career progression requirements for each of these roles?
People.2.9.remarks: Career progression for roles can be documented through training, certification, experience and soft skills requirements
guidances: Basic documentation of career progression for roles
Single document, full description of career progression for roles
Document completed, approved and formally published

People.2.10.title: Do you regularly revise or update the role descriptions?
People.2.10.remarks: To revise is to review and verify whether to documentation is still correct or requires an update
guidances: Documentation is reviewed ad-hoc, not using a structured approach
Documentation is reviewed ad-hoc, using a structured approach
Documentation is regularly and informally reviewed and updated
Documentation is regularly and formally reviewed and updated

People.3.1.title: Do you have a job rotation plan in place?
People.3.1.remarks: Job rotation can be used to train employees in a variety of tasks and avoid too much routine
guidances: A plan covering some roles is in place, but not operational
A plan covering some roles is in place and operational
A plan covering all roles is in place, but not formalized
A plan covering all roles is in place and formalized

People.3.2.title: Do you have a career progression process in place?
guidances: No career progression process is in place
A process covering some roles is in place, but not operational
A process covering some roles is in place and operational
A process covering all roles is in place, but not formalized
A process covering all roles is in place and formalized

People.3.3.title: Do you have a talent management process in place?
People.3.3.remarks: Talent should be adequately managed to retain such staff and fully develop their potential.
guidances: No talent management process in place
Talent management is performed at an ad-hoc basis
A basic talent management process is in place
A full process is in place, but not performing effectively
A full talent management process is in place and performing effectively

People.3.4.title: Do you have team diversity goals?
People.3.4.remarks: e.g. background diversity, ethnic diversity, gender diversity, etc.
guidances: Diversity goals are recognized but not defined
Diversity goals are defined but not formalized
Diversity goals have been formally defined and are not met
Diversity goals have been formally defined and are met

People.3.5.title: Have you established team goals?
People.3.5.remarks: Team goals help to bring focus to the team and monitor progress
guidances: Team goals are determined, but not formally documented
Team goals are determined, and formally documented
Team goals are determined and documented, but not tracked

Services.5.16.title: Please specify capabilities and artefacts of the threat hunting process:

Services.5.16.1.title: Hash value hunting
Services.5.16.1.remarks: 'Trivial', lowest added value as these change swiftly
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.2.title: IP address hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.3.title: Domain name hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.4.title: Network artefact hunting
Services.5.16.4.remarks: 'Annoying', include network flow, packet capture, proxy logs, active network connections, historic connections, ports and services
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.5.title: Host-based artefact hunting
Services.5.16.5.remarks: 'Annoying', includes users, processes, services, drivers, files, registry, hardware, memory, disk activity, network connections, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.6.title: Adversary tools hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.7.title: Adversary TTP hunting
Services.5.16.7.remarks: 'Tough!', requires detailed knowledge of adversaries and their modus operandi
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.8.title: Inbound threat hunting
Services.5.16.8.remarks: Hunting for inbound threats such as inbound connections, DNS zone transfers, inbound emails
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.9.title: Outbound threat hunting
Services.5.16.9.remarks: Hunting for outbound threats such as C&C traffic, outbound emails
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.10.title: Internal threat hunting
Services.5.16.10.remarks: Hunting for threats inside the organization. Hunting may focus on lateral movement or anomalous network connections
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.11.title: Outlier detection
Services.5.16.11.remarks: Using statistical methods to detect outliers, such as least frequency of occurrence
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.12.title: Hunting coverage
Services.5.16.12.remarks: How well does the hunting process cover your environment? All assets & network traffic, or only partially? Scalability is key
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.13.title: Leveraging of existing tooling
Services.5.16.13.remarks: Existing tools may include the SIEM system, firewall analysis tools, etc.
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.14.title: Custom hunting scripts and tools
Services.5.16.14.remarks: Any custom scripts to assist the hunting process. May include scripts to scan end-points for particular artifacts
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.15.title: Dedicated hunting platform
Services.5.16.15.remarks: Dedicated tooling for the hunting process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.16.title: Continuous hunting data collection
Services.5.16.16.remarks: Continuous collection of information can be used to alert on indicators and to preserve system state
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.17.title: Historic hunting
Services.5.16.17.remarks: Hunting for indicators that may have been present on end-points in the past. Requires some sort of saved state
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.18.title: Automated hunting
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.19.title: Hunt alerting
Services.5.16.19.remarks: Automated alerting based on queries performed in the hunting process
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.20.title: Vulnerability information integration
Services.5.16.20.remarks: Integration of vulnerability information into the hunting process to provide additional context
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.5.16.21.title: Threat intelligence integration
Services.5.16.21.remarks: Integration of threat intelligence information into the hunting process, threat hunts should be driven by threat intelligence
guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.6.15.6.title: Authenticated scanning

Services.6.15.11.title: Trend identification

Services.6.15.12.title: Enterprise vulnerability repository

Services.6.15.13.title: Enterprise application inventory

guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.6.15.14.title: Vulnerability Management procedures

guidances: Fully implemented, documented, approved, actively improved

Services.6.15.15.title: Scanning policy tuning
